official_title: A bill to provide for improved drug abuse treatment and prevention.
short_title: Drug and Alcohol Abuse Treatment and Prevention Improvement Act of 1990
subjects: Federal aid to law enforcement agencies
Federal aid to maternal health services
Treatment and rehabilitation of narcotic addicts

summary.text: Drug and Alcohol Abuse Treatment and Prevention Improvement Act of 1990 - Title I: Improvement and Expansion of Grant Programs - Establishes in the Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health Administration (ADAMHA) the Office for Treatment Improvement (Treatment Office) to: (1) collaborate with the Directors of the Office for Substance Abuse Prevention, the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA), the Bureau of Maternal and Child Health, and the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; (2) evaluate State plans and carry out programs under existing provisions; (3) train providers of prehospital emergency medical services; (4) conduct or support described programs; and (5) take other actions with regard to treatment. Authorizes appropriations. Revises requirements and other matters relating to an existing program regarding drug and alcohol abuse model projects for pregnant and postpartum women and their infants. Requires the Director of the Treatment Office to collaborate on issues relating to maternal substance abuse with all other relevant Federal agencies. Authorizes appropriations. Transfers from the Administrator of ADAMHA to the Director of NIDA authority to make grants for drug abuse demonstration projects of national significance. Requires the Director of the Treatment Office to establish programs to provide grants to: (1) eligible institutions to provide training services to increase the supply of drug and alcohol treatment of professionals; and (2) public and nonprofit private entities that provide drug and alcohol treatment services to individuals under criminal justice supervision. Authorizes appropriations. Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) make grants to community coalitions for substance abuse prevention programs and activities; and (2) establish and implement a program to inform the public of dangers to maternal and child health resulting from drug and alcohol use during pregnancy and the post partum period. Authorizes appropriations. Title II: Revision of the ADAMHA Block Grant Program - Revises the Block Grant formula. Provides for the use of allotments by States for: (1) inpatient hospital or accredited nonhospital drug treatment services pursuant to a contractual arrangement with a hospital if certain conditions are met; (2) counseling to family members of drug abusers; and (3) treatment programs for substance abusers in State and local criminal and juvenile justice systems. Requires States to develop and submit to the Secretary annually for review and approval a statewide Substance Abuse Treatment Plan. Requires the Director of the Treatment Office to establish a model State treatment plan. Directs the Secretary to issue guidelines for plans. Title III: Pharmacotherapy Development - Pharmacotherapy Development Act of 1990 - Part A: Federal Medication Development Program - Amends the Public Health Service Act (PHSA) to establish in ADAMHA a Medications Development Program through which the Administrator of ADAMHA shall: (1) conduct periodic meetings with the Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to discuss measures that may facilitate the approval process of drug addiction treatments; (2) encourage and promote expanded research programs, investigations, experiments, and studies into the development of medications to treat drug and alcohol addiction and related mental disorders; (3) establish research facilities; (4) report on the activities of other relevant agencies relating to the development and use of pharmacotherapeutic treatments for drug addiction; (5) collect, analyze, and disseminate data and the results of such research on the development and use of pharmacotherapeutic treatments for drug and alcohol addiction and related mental disorders; and (6) support training in the basic sciences and clinical disciplines related to the pharmacotherapeutic treatment of drug and alcohol addiction and related mental disorders. Establishes reporting requirements by the Administrator of ADAMHA. Requires the Administrator of National Drug Control Policy to incorporate reports submitted under this Act into the National Drug Control Strategy. Requires the Administrator of ADAMHA to provide for proper scientific review of all research grants, cooperative agreements, and contracts over which the Administrator has authority. Authorizes appropriations. Part B: Study on Private Sector Development of Pharmacotherapeutics - Directs the Commissioner to: (1) prepare a report on the role of the private sector in the development of anti-addiction medications, including legislative proposals designed to encourage private sector development of such medications; and (2) submit such report, within one year, to the appropriate congressional committees. Part C: Study on Medications Review Process Reform - Directs the Commissioner to: (1) prepare a report on the process by which anti-addiction medications receive marketing approval from the FDA, assessing the feasibility of expediting the process in a manner consistent with public safety; and (2) submit such report, within one year, to the appropriate congressional committees. Part D: High Priority Research Areas - Expresses the sense of the Congress that the Medications Development Division (MDD) of NIDA shall devote special attention and resources to achieving the development of a methadone alternative, a long-acting narcotic antagonist, a cocaine blocking treatment, a cocaine-blocker/narcotic antagonist treatment, medications to treat addictions to methamphetamine, medications to treat pregnant addicts and their fetuses, and medications to treat the offspring of addicted mothers. Part E: Report by the Surgeon General - Requires: (1) the Director of MDD to establish a panel of independent experts in the field of pharmacotherapeutic treatment of drug addiction to assess the national strategy for developing such treatments and make appropriate recommendations; and (2) the Surgeon General of the United States to submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report setting forth recommendations of such panel and assessing the progress of the nation toward development of safe, efficacious pharmacological treatments for drug addiction. Title IV: Children of Substance Abusers and At-Risk Families - Children of Substance Abusers Act - Amends the PHSA to require the Secretary of HHS to make grants to eligible entities to pay for the Federal share of costs of establishing programs to provide community outreach services and services for children of substance abusers. Specifies that such services shall include, in the case of: (1) children of substance abusers, periodic evaluation of children for developmental, psychological, and medical problems, primary pediatric care, preventive counseling, and referral to related services; (2) substance abusers, primary health care and mental health services, consultation and referral regarding subsequent pregnancies and life options, remedial education, and referral to related services; and (3) substance abusers, spouses, extended family members, caretakers of children, and other significant people in the lives of substance abusers or children of substance abusers, therapeutic intervention services (including parental and joint counseling sessions), child care, parenting education and peer support groups, transportation services (where appropriate), and aftercare services. Requires programs established through grants under this Act to: (1) provide comprehensive services directed at the needs of the entire family; (2) be accessible to recipients of community outreach services and services for children of substance abusers; (3) maintain the confidentiality of information about substance abusers and children of substance abusers with respect to treatment or receipt of services; (4) provide long-term services; and (5) provide a range of services corresponding to the varying needs of the recipients. Sets forth additional requirements with respect to: (1) the distribution of grant awards, giving priority to areas with a high incidence of poverty, children of substance abusers, infant mortality, and child abuse and neglect; (2) application and eligibiity procedures and requirements; and (3) the Federal share of grants (90 percent). Directs the Secretary to make grants to eligible entities to train interdisciplinary teams to provide support to, and arrange services for, caretakers of children of substance abusers. Authorizes such entities to provide training, case support, and consultation to interdisciplinary teams of personnel from child protective services or child welfare agencies and from public health, mental health, or social services agencies. Specifies that such training shall: (1) include instruction on the effects of prenatal substance abuse, the implications on infant care, health, and development, and the methods of providing instruction and support for caretakers of substance abusers; (2) support an approach to service delivery that is interagency, interdisciplinary, comprehensive, oriented toward case management, and focused on improving the health and development of the child; (3) be conducted in sessions that include participants from both child protective or welfare agencies and public health, mental health, or social services agencies; and (4) be conducted in classroom, home-based, and clinical settings. Sets forth application requirements. Directs the Secretary to make competitive grants for periods of three to five years to eligible entities to pay for the Federal share of the costs of providing home visiting services to eligible families. Specifies that the purposes of such grants are to: (1) increase the use of prenatal and post partum care; (2) reduce the incidence of infants born prematurely, with low birthweight, or with other impairments associated with maternal substance abuse; (3) assist pregnant women and mothers of children below age three whose children have experienced, or are at risk of experiencing, a health or developmental complication in obtaining treatment for drug or alcohol abuse and other services necessary to meet the special needs of the women; (4) reduce the incidence of child abuse and neglect; and (5) promote other measures to encourage appropriate growth and development of children. Requires the Secretary to give priority in awarding grants to entities that have experience in providing outreach and preventive public health services to at-risk populations and have demonstrated a commitment to serving low income and uninsured individuals and families. Sets forth application and eligibility requirements. Specifies that the Federal share of such grants shall be 90 percent. Requires the Secretary to: (1) ensure coordination of the activities and services under this Act; (2) conduct evaluations to determine program effectiveness; and (3) prepare and submit annual reports to the appropriate congressional committees. Authorizes appropriations. Directs the Secretary to study and report to specified congressional committees on: (1) the various efforts within the Department of HHS to address the needs of parents who are substance abusers and the needs of the children of such parents; and (2) the ways in which coordination of efforts can be improved and duplication of efforts reduced. Title V: Anti-Drug Education - Anti-Drug Education Act of 1990 - Amends the Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act to require that State programs to promote, establish, and maintain drug-free school zones include such steps as: (1) drug-abuse education and prevention programs and enforcement policies designed to eliminate the illicit use of alcohol and drugs in such zones; (2) informing the community of laws relating to illegal drugs as they affect school children and of the perimeters of the drug-free school zones; (3) employing the services of the local or substate regional advisory council on drug abuse education and prevention as a resource for advice and support; and (4) communication to students, teachers, athletic directors, and other school personnel by administrators that illicit and harmful activities will not be tolerated within schools and surrounding environments. Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) or consortia of LEAs and private nonprofit entities to provide drug abuse education, prevention, or counseling services to students in kindergarten through grade 12. Sets forth eligibility and application requirements. Authorizes appropriations. Authorizes the use of funds, in the case of an LEA that determines that it provides sufficient drug and alcohol abuse education during regular school hours, for after-school programs that provide drug and alcohol abuse education for school-aged children. Specifies that grants for teacher training programs shall be used for the training of elementary and secondary school teachers and administrators and for other elementary and secondary school personnel. Directs the Secretary to give priority to making a substantial number of grants to qualified State educational agencies, LEAs, and institutions of higher education for programs to train counselors, social workers, psychologists, or nurses. Authorizes the Secretary to make a grant to any private nonprofit agency that has an agreement with an LEA to provide training in drug abuse counseling for individuals who will provide such counseling in the schools of such LEA. Sets forth application requirements. Increases appropriations for drug abuse education and prevention programs. Requires local recipients of funds under this Act, in any publication or public announcement, to clearly identify any program assisted under this Act as a Federal program funded under the Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1986. Title VI: Miscellaneous Provisions - Directs the Secretary of HHS to: (1) review existing data and research as to whether there is a relationship between an individual's receptivity to use or consume legal drugs and the consumption or abuse of illegal drugs; (2) determine whether additional research is necessary; and (3) report to specified congressional committees on the results of the review. Requires the Secretary of Education to prepare and submit to the appropriate congressional committees and the President a report concerning the preparedness of the U.S. school system to meet the special needs of children born affected by alcohol or drugs. Amends the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act to authorize and increase appropriations for grants to States for child abuse and neglect prevention and treatment programs. Amends the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 to provide that, in determining the weight of a "mixture or substance" under such Act, the court shall not include the weight of: (1) the carrier upon which the controlled substance is placed or by which it is transported; or (2) any chemical or other substance used in the manufacture of the controlled substance and then discarded. Amends the Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1986 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award grants to consortia of LEAS and entities that have experience in assisting LEAs to provide instruction to students in kindergarten through grade 6 designed to teach such students to recognize and resist pressures that influence such students to use illicit drugs or alcohol. Bars eligibility for such grants unless such consortia agree to use assistance so provided for the provision of services that include: (1) drug abuse resistance education; (2) provisions for parental involvement; (3) classroom instruction by uniformed law enforcement officials, coupled with activities taught by the regular classroom teacher; (4) the use of student leaders to influence younger students not to use drugs; (5) an emphasis on activity-oriented techniques designed to encourage student-generated responses to problem-solving situations; and (6) the award of a certificate of achievement to each student who participants in a drug abuse resistance education program. Sets forth application requirements. Authorizes appropriations. Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Commissioner to establish a drug salvager compensation program to decrease the availability of drugs that are acquired through the salvage of shipments of pharmaceuticals and controlled substances through the provision of assistance to salvagers of such products to enable them to return such product to the manufacturer or to destroy such product. Sets forth requirements with respect to: (1) contracts for the salvage of such products; (2) assignment of a Drug Enforcement Administration number; (3) reporting requirements; and (4) funding of the program.
